intro: Rubus vexatus var. subtiliaceus, commonly known as the slender blackberry. It is a deciduous shrub native to the Pacific Northwest of North America, characterized by its thorny stems and trifoliate leaves. The plant produces small, dark purple berries that are typically consumed by wildlife. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks. Botanically, it is distinguished by its finely hairy stems and small, elliptical leaves with serrated edges.
